1.QUESTION: The following statements about biostatistics are correct

OPTION.A: It can be used for sentinel surveys
OPTION.B: It is key in decision making
OPTION.C: Most of the information are on changing trends
OPTION.D: Inductive statistics is similar to inferential statistics
OPTION.E: Deductive statistics is inferior to inductive statistics

1.EXPLANATION: Biostatistics is used for sentinel surveys, informs decision making, analyzes trends, and inductive statistics aligns with inferential statistics. Deductive statistics is not inferior.

2.QUESTION: The following are key components of Health Information System except

OPTION.C: Health chronicles

2.EXPLANATION: Health chronicles is not considered a key component; others like demographics, resources, utilization, and cost analysis are core components.

3.QUESTION: Concerning variables, the following statements are correct

OPTION.A: It is a set of values recorded continuously
OPTION.B: It is the aspect of an individual that is measured
OPTION.C: Numerical variables are commoner in nature
OPTION.D: Culture result is an example of binary variable

3.EXPLANATION: All listed statements are correct definitions and examples related to variables.

4.QUESTION: Subject variation in research measurement can occur as a result of

OPTION.C: Faulty technique used

4.EXPLANATION: All listed factors contribute to variation in research measurements.

5.QUESTION: About frequency table distribution, the following issus raised are correct

OPTION.B: It is used for early data exploration
OPTION.C: In qualitative data presentation, its second column contains mutually exclusive variables
OPTION.D: All class intervals must be unique
OPTION.E: Class limits are the most important part

5.EXPLANATION: All listed properties are important for constructing and interpreting frequency tables.

6.QUESTION: An epidemic is

OPTION.A: Characterized by a number of cases clearly in excess of normal expectancy
OPTION.B: Relative to the usual frequency of the disease irrespective of the number of cases
OPTION.C: Can be a single case of a communicable disease long absent from the population

6.EXPLANATION: An epidemic may include all three scenarios; hence 'all of the above' is correct.

7.QUESTION: The epidemiological tool which expresses a relation in size between two random quantities could be

OPTION.C: Sensitivity

7.EXPLANATION: A ratio specifically expresses the relationship between two quantities.

8.QUESTION: Which of the following is not primary prevention

OPTION.C: Screening for early detection and prompt treatment

8.EXPLANATION: Screening and early treatment is secondary prevention, not primary prevention.

9.QUESTION: The denominator for maternal mortality ratio is

OPTION.A: Number of women of child bearing age
OPTION.C: Number of live and still births

9.EXPLANATION: Maternal mortality ratio is calculated per 100,000 live births.

10.QUESTION: The ability of a screening test to correctly identify those who have a disease is called

OPTION.C: Specificity

10.EXPLANATION: Sensitivity measures the proportion of true positives correctly identified.

11.QUESTION: A patient walks into a Heart-to-Heart of your rural practice centre with a positive RVST screening(using only determine) referral from another centre far from the patient's abode, which of the following steps includes the right lines of action.

OPTION.A: Start the client on Anti-retroviral drug first
OPTION.B: Send the client for confirmatory test with Western Blot
OPTION.C: Send the patient for serial testing with another type of test kit
OPTION.D: If positive, do a post-test counselling

11.EXPLANATION: Serial testing with a different test kit is recommended (C), followed by post-test counselling (D).

12.QUESTION: Concerning meningitis outbreaks in Nigeria, correct statements are

OPTION.A: Antigenic group C has been implicated in one of the outbreaks in 2017
OPTION.B: The outbreaks have spread beyond Northern Nigeria
OPTION.C: Mass immunization is not an effective control measure
OPTION.D: The recommended drug of choice for close contacts of cases is Isoniazid
OPTION.E: Gathering in large numbers during an outbreak is not encouraged

12.EXPLANATION: Group C caused outbreaks (A), outbreaks spread beyond North (B), and gatherings discouraged (E). Mass immunization is effective; Isoniazid not recommended.

13.QUESTION: In view of the recent outbreak of Lassa fever in different Health Care Facilities in the country

OPTION.A: Hospitals must form Infection Prevention and Control Committees
OPTION.B: Standard Operating Procedures(SOPs) need not be established for every sections of the hospital due to A above
OPTION.C: Screening of all patients for fever with isolation area is mandatory
OPTION.D: Search for epidemiological link is of little relevance
OPTION.E: Universal precaution should be ensured by all

13.EXPLANATION: IPC committees, fever screening/isolation, and universal precautions are essential. SOPs and ignoring links are incorrect.

14.QUESTION: Activities to control sexually transmitted infections include the following

OPTION.C: Screening of every adult
OPTION.E: Use of all forms of family planning

14.EXPLANATION: STI control includes tracing, education, and treating infected individuals.

15.QUESTION: The infective agents for the following diseases in man are

OPTION.C: Schistosomiasis - metacercaria

15.EXPLANATION: Malaria: merozoites (A), Fasciola: cercaria (D), Taenia saginata: cysticercus (E). Dracunculiasis and Schistosomiasis infective forms differ.

16.QUESTION: Community Medicine is

OPTION.A: A combination of clinical medicine and public health
OPTION.C: Practised by both the doctor and the community nurse
OPTION.D: Practised by all community health workers

16.EXPLANATION: Community medicine integrates clinical medicine and public health (A), applied to communities (B), practiced by doctors and nurses (C).

17.QUESTION: Human Ecology studies

OPTION.A: The interaction between humans and animals
OPTION.B: The interaction of humans with their total environment
OPTION.C: Human surroundings and the effects they produce in the lives of men
OPTION.D: Only the influence of humans on their environment
OPTION.E: The impact of human activities on the ecosystem

17.EXPLANATION: Human ecology studies human interactions with their environment (B,C,E).

18.QUESTION: Culture is

OPTION.C: Acquired

18.EXPLANATION: Culture is shared, acquired, and dynamic. It is not static or non-integrated.

19.QUESTION: Current concepts of health include

OPTION.B: Health as a way of life
OPTION.C: Health as a potential

19.EXPLANATION: Modern concepts view health as dynamic, a way of life, potential, and a social goal.

20.QUESTION: Sociology in Medicine deals with

OPTION.B: The social aspects of health organizations
OPTION.C: The social aspects of health and disease
OPTION.D: What people believe and do about health and illness

20.EXPLANATION: Sociology in medicine covers all listed aspects.

21.QUESTION: Concerning Vitamin A deficiency

OPTION.A: Fortification of flour and vegetable oil is possible
OPTION.B: Vitamin A supplements can be given to lactating mothers and babies
OPTION.C: Vitamin A deficiency with child mortality
OPTION.D: Vitamin A supplementation is highly effective, sustainable but is very expensive
OPTION.E: All of the above statements are true

21.EXPLANATION: All listed statements accurately describe interventions and consequences of vitamin A deficiency.

22.QUESTION: Cereals are deficient in

OPTION.C: Lysine

22.EXPLANATION: Cereals are commonly deficient in lysine.

23.QUESTION: Factors influencing food preference include

OPTION.C: Genetic factors

23.EXPLANATION: All listed factors influence food preferences.

24.QUESTION: Direct methods of assessment of nutritional status include

OPTION.C: Birth weight

24.EXPLANATION: Direct anthropometric measurements and BMI are standard; clinic records and lab tests are indirect.

25.QUESTION: Arthropods of medical importance include

OPTION.C: Ticks

25.EXPLANATION: Non-biting flies, mosquitoes, and ticks are medically important vectors.

26.QUESTION: The following are formal sources of literature in research

OPTION.C: Search engines-Google

26.EXPLANATION: Search engines like Google are not formal research sources; others are.

27.QUESTION: Ethical issues in research involve

OPTION.C: Reasons for the study
OPTION.D: Permission for access to medical records

27.EXPLANATION: Ethical issues focus on consent, withdrawal, privacy, and feedback; the reason for study is not an ethical requirement.

28.QUESTION: The following are quantitative methods of data collection except

OPTION.C: Observational Checklists

28.EXPLANATION: Key informant interviews are qualitative, not quantitative.

29.QUESTION: The following are true as regards uses of water in public health

OPTION.A: Minimum of 200-400L/person/day is needed in rural areas
OPTION.B: Minimum of 20-60 L/person/day is needed in urban areas
OPTION.C: At least 50 L/day will be adequate for maintaining good health
OPTION.D: Serves in sports & medium for recreations e.g. swimming, boating
OPTION.E: Water scarcity is the aetiologic basis for Ebola Virus Disease

29.EXPLANATION: All listed are correct uses; water scarcity is not the cause of Ebola.

30.QUESTION: In assessing water quality

OPTION.A: Coliform organisms are the only organisms used as indicators of recent faecal pollution
OPTION.C: A coliform count of 10/100ml is regarded as suspicious
OPTION.D: Water with turbidity of <5 NTU is acceptable
OPTION.E: Cyanide levels of not more than <0.05mg/l is safe

30.EXPLANATION: Coliforms are indicators but not the only ones; physical assessment alone is not conclusive.

31.QUESTION: The health effects of poorly disposed refuse include

OPTION.C: Mosquito-borne diseases

31.EXPLANATION: Poor refuse disposal causes water pollution, vector breeding, mosquito-borne and murine typhus infections; stress is not directly caused.

32.QUESTION: The characteristics of a good sanitary well include

OPTION.A: Should be sited at least 10 metres and uphill from any potential source of pollution
OPTION.B: Water should be drawn by a pump or at least a permanent bucket attached to the well
OPTION.C: Concrete platform about two feet high surrounded by a concrete apron to drain waste water
OPTION.E: There should be water-tight lining of at least 30 feet from the surface

32.EXPLANATION: All listed features contribute to a sanitary well. D (all of the above) is correct; lining (E) ensures safety.

33.QUESTION: The following are characteristics of good sewage disposal include

OPTION.A: Must not pollute surface soil, surface water, or underground water
OPTION.C: Must be inaccessible to flies or animals
OPTION.E: Method should be simple, cheap and culturally acceptable

33.EXPLANATION: Good sewage disposal prevents pollution, avoids vector access, and is simple and culturally acceptable.

34.QUESTION: In the segregation of biomedical wastes, the following is/are correct

OPTION.C: Sharps - Red

34.EXPLANATION: Infectious waste should be red or yellow; brown is incorrect.

35.QUESTION: Which of the following definition is/are correct

OPTION.B: Sullage - network of sewers from the same area that discharges into a common pool
OPTION.C: Sewer - waste water from kitchen, bathrooms, laundry, etc that take away faeces from the toilet
OPTION.D: Sewerage - connection of pipes that take away faeces from the bath and laundry
OPTION.E: Sullarage - connection of pipes in different ways

35.EXPLANATION: Sullage definition is incorrect; others are accurate.

36.QUESTION: Contraceptive oral pills help in birth control by

OPTION.C: Killing of sperms
OPTION.D: Efficacy with regular use is over 84%
OPTION.E: Thickening the mucous on the cervix

36.EXPLANATION: Oral contraceptives prevent ovulation, thicken cervical mucus, and have high efficacy; they do not kill ova or sperms.

37.QUESTION: Factors vital for successful conception include

OPTION.A: The sperm count of the male partner must be satisfactory in every parameter
OPTION.B: The mucous membrane of the cervix must facilitate transport of active spermatozoa
OPTION.C: Existence of certain congenital anomalies in the reproductive system always affects fertilization
OPTION.D: The female hormones especially progesterone and androgen must be adequate

37.EXPLANATION: All listed factors are crucial for successful conception.

38.QUESTION: The definition of Primary Health Care covers

OPTION.C: At a cost that individuals and families can afford at every stage of development
OPTION.D: In a spirit of self-reliance and self-determination

38.EXPLANATION: PHC is basic, accessible, affordable, participatory, and self-reliant; advanced care is not included.

39.QUESTION: In Nigeria, PHC workers ideally include

OPTION.C: Midwives

39.EXPLANATION: Doctors are not typically classified as PHC workers in Nigeria; CHEWs, CHOs, midwives, and nurses are.

40.QUESTION: Health Economics covers

OPTION.C: Opportunity cost and efficient use of scarce resources to produce commodities for satisfaction of unlimited needs and wants
OPTION.E: Study of proper allocation of resources

40.EXPLANATION: All listed elements are central topics in health economics.

41.QUESTION: The following are true about the forms of Economic Evaluation

OPTION.A: Cost minimization analysis is also called Cost Analysis
OPTION.B: Cost-benefit Analysis has both numerator and denominator in terms of cost
OPTION.C: Cost-effectiveness Analysis is also called Cost Analysis
OPTION.D: Cost-Utilization Analysis has Quality Unadjusted Life Years as an outcome
OPTION.E: Cost-Utilization Analysis has Healthy Life Years (HLY) as an outcome

41.EXPLANATION: Cost-effectiveness is not called cost analysis; others are correctly described.

42.QUESTION: Factors that affect Demand in Health Economics include

OPTION.C: Human resources

42.EXPLANATION: All listed factors affect demand; hence 'all of the above' is correct.

43.QUESTION: Pareto efficiency can be described as

OPTION.A: Want denied when choice is made
OPTION.C: Contingent valuation
OPTION.D: Making one person better off without making someone else worse off

43.EXPLANATION: Pareto efficiency refers to improving someoneâ€™s position without harming others.

44.QUESTION: Concerning Impairment, Disability and Handicap

OPTION.A: Impairment is any loss of psychological function
OPTION.B: Impairment is any abnormality of anatomical structure
OPTION.C: Disability is a restriction of ability to perform an activity
OPTION.D: Disability is abnormality of anatomical structure
OPTION.E: Handicap is a restriction depending on age, sex and cultural factors of the individual

44.EXPLANATION: Impairment relates to structural or functional loss (B), disability restricts activity (C), handicap is social disadvantage (E).

45.QUESTION: The following are true about Adoption

OPTION.A: Adoption is a permanent legal arrangement whereby the care of a child is taken up by a responsible woman
OPTION.B: The child takes up the family name
OPTION.C: The child is entitled to an inheritance when adoptive parents die
OPTION.D: The adoptive parents must be educated
OPTION.E: The adoptive parents must be over 21 years of age

45.EXPLANATION: Adoption is legal and allows inheritance (B,C) and requires parents to be over 21 (E). Responsibility is not limited to women (A) and education is not mandatory (D).

46.QUESTION: Concerning intelligent quotient (IQ)

OPTION.A: The WHO uses IQ to assess mental proficiency
OPTION.C: Profound mental retardation <20
OPTION.E: People with I.Q. > 50 are incapable of living alone or guarding against exploitation

46.EXPLANATION: All listed IQ ranges and facts are correct.

47.QUESTION: Functions of the World Health Organization include

OPTION.B: Provision of international sanitary regulation to prevent spread of disease without traffic interference
OPTION.C: Financial assistance to member nations

47.EXPLANATION: WHO performs all listed functions; hence 'all of the above' is correct.

48.QUESTION: Concerning International Health Regulations (IHR)

OPTION.A: It was first adopted by the Health Assembly in 1969
OPTION.C: IHR 2005 came into force on 15 June 2007
OPTION.E: Only A and C are correct

48.EXPLANATION: IHR was adopted in 1969 (A) and 2005 revision came into force in 2007 (C).

49.QUESTION: The following practices at workplace can be termed as a form of containment

OPTION.C: Ventilation

49.EXPLANATION: All listed methods are containment measures to reduce workplace hazards.

50.QUESTION: The following are correctly matched historical figures and works

OPTION.B: Charles Turner Thackrah - Effects of the principal acts of trade and profession on health and longevity
OPTION.C: Thomas Percival - De morbis artificum diatriba
OPTION.D: Bernardino Ramazzini - Health and morals of apprentices act 1802
OPTION.E: Sir Thomas Legg - lead poisoning and lead absorption

50.EXPLANATION: Sir Thomas Legg is incorrectly matched; others correctly correspond to their works.
